urn:contentItem:5J2F-F681-DXH2-63B0-00000-00EMC Corp at Goldman Sachs Technology Conference - Final2016-02-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:31ZLexisNexis020916a5914258.758EMC Corp at Goldman Sachs Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Joe Tucci

EMC Corp - Chairman, CEO

* Bill Green

EMC Corp - Lead Director

Conference Call Participants

* Simona Jankowski

Goldman Sachs - Analyst

* Debbie

Goldman Sachs - Analyst

Presentation

DEBBIE GOLDMAN SACHS, ANALYST: We're very delighted to welcome EMC and I think our next speaker needs very little introduction. Joe Tucci, the Chairman and CEO of EMC who has been in that role since 2001. As you all know, he has been at the help of a pretty incredible transformation of a storage company into a very successful federation business that is now in the midst of a transformative transaction with Dell. In addition to Joe, we're going to be having with us on stage Bill Green who is the Lead Independent Director of EMC and the former Chairman and CEO of Accenture. So with that, welcome on stage.

Questions and Answers

DEBBIE GOLDMAN SACHS: Bright lights on you guys. So I'm just going to kick off a couple questions and turn it over to Simona. But I think the big question people are wondering for you, Joe, and for Bill, what have you guys been up to lately? What's new?

JOE TUCCI, CHAIRMAN, CEO, EMC CORP: Not much. You know, the lawyers are going to absolutely kill me if I don't go back a slide. And I hate doing this, but Bill and I may well make some forward-looking statements and some additional comments and we really urge you to check our filings with the SEC. So thank you for being with us today and kind of sorry for that, but very, very important, so please check those filings. Debbie, go ahead.

DEBBIE GOLDMAN SACHS: You tell us. What's been preoccupying both of you over the last couple of months?

JOE TUCCI: Well obviously first and foremost on our mind has been the merger with Dell. It certainly has garnered a lot of excitement. And to be honest, Bill and I both know it's generated some angst amongst the investor bases, both investor bases of EMC and investor base of VMware. But we really, truly believe that this was a fantastic and indeed the best alternative and answer for our shareholders, our customers and our people around the world, our 70,000 people around the world. We'll get into that I'm sure as questions, as the session comes.

We really believe, and we've been very vocal in talking about the massive secular changes that are facing this industry in mobile, around telemetry, around cloud computing, around digital transformation the companies are going to go through, the need for security. We, over time, that's dominated our internal thoughts and we've shaped our company to address the opportunities. Because obviously those, all those have a disruptive side, but all those have massive opportunity attached to them and we've been making sure that we well-face into this. And I think with Dell we get a better opportunity to capitalize on all these great things that are going to happen in information technology.

It gives us great leadership in servers and storage, in conversion infrastructure, in virtualization, in software defined datacenter and cloud platforms, areas of security, so it's a great coming together, creates a great platform, in client I should add, give us a great platform to serve our customers and make sure that we hopefully give you something that really is fair and a good outcome. So this is what's been dominating our mind and we want to make sure that this works really well for you and everybody else that's involved. Bill, you want to --

BILL GREEN, LEAD DIRECTOR, EMC CORP: Yeah, I suppose it's out of character that a Director -- usually they keep directors away from the investors because they're afraid they might go off script I suppose. But I look at it as my job, I'm the Lead Director of EMC, I'm honored to be that. I failed retirement. I was with Accenture for 36 years and when you retire, of course, everyone wants you to be on their board. And there were a bunch of them and Joe came by and I was lucky enough to know the company and know the people. And I just said to myself, these guys have something special, I want to be part of building something great. And so I joined the EMC board and became the Lead Director.

My job is to represent our shareholders. That's what I have to solve for and I have to work closely with the management team and the board to do that. And so we've been at this for quite a while. The way you take on a transformation is from a position of strength. And so as we assessed ourselves and we looked as a board at our company and what we had, and most importantly the underlying assets that had either been built or acquired over a period of time, and then the talent that we have, and then you lay that up against the market that we're facing. The market we're seeing today and the rise of digitization and the cloud and all these things, isn't a surprise. We could see that coming. So the question is, how do you get the most value out of what we have on behalf of your shareholders? How do you solve for the needs of your customers that stick with you day in and day out? And how do you provide opportunities for your people to take a good thing and make it a great thing?

And so the process on the board, which is our job, was one of rigor and discipline to look at all the alternatives for the company that was the EMC Federation. Everything we could do ourselves that would enhance our position to serve our customers and reward our shareholders. And then be ready to change, even when you're at the top of your game, to look at opportunities in the market. And as part of looking at those opportunities in the market, it was recognizing, and Joe has always articulated this to our board, that consolidation was something that was going to continue to happen in this industry. I think that's absolutely true. And so we looked hard at where can we have one plus one equals three? And in working through that with the likely kind of companies that are out there, the Dell opportunity came up and so we were very thoughtful about it, very rigorous about it. I'll talk about some of that later in terms of the things we did to protect our shareholders and enhance the shareholder value. But most importantly, we had the opportunity to solve for building something great. We had the opportunity to take capability and assets, knowledge and know how, and most of all ambition of a company we represented and another company and combine them together to build one of the world's great companies.

And so yes, we solved for the right financial deal and value for our shareholders, but we also solved for leveraging the assets, knowledge, knowhow, people and really a couple of decades of Joe's work to build a company that is incredibly special. And that's the journey that we've started on and as a board we're incredibly proud with the work we did on behalf of our shareholders to do that.

DEBBIE GOLDMAN SACHS: Joe, what surprised you the most about the last 4 or 5 months?

JOE TUCCI: First of all, on the positive side, the overwhelmingly positive reception from our customers. Because at the end of the day, the customers are the ultimate vote if a company is going to be successful or a transaction is going to be successful. And the over -- I'm using the word overwhelmingly positive and I'm using it in all honesty and my own style is I always try to be extremely straight with you all the time, and it's overwhelmingly positive for our customers.

If you look at the strengths we have, we believe that this new company, we're beyond the must look at list, must consider list, anytime there's a significant bid going down in anything that matters in IT. That's a great place to be in life. So you as shareholders, VMware shareholders, I mean basically end up on the other side, you say from the EMC point of view I get cash, but on the VMware point of view, the stock that you own, the common stock or the letter stock that you will be getting, gives you a great opportunity. And I think when you look at what VMware can do with that massive $80 billion company helping push their great software technology, and I mean great software technology. This is a company with three software product lines that are over $1 billion of revenue today, and a fourth in networking, virtual networking product line on the cusp of becoming a fourth $1 billion plus revenue stream. This is a special company. And again, what you get with this is you get to own a piece of that special company for as long as you want obviously. You can always -- it will be very liquid when this is done.

And then of course it's the connection where Michael Dell and Silver Lake will own 27% to 30% of this company when it's done and they're going to operate this in the best interests of VMware. I know there is fears out there that they will raid the balance sheet. That is unfounded. VMware's cash will be VMWare's cash. VMware will use that cash to expand its business, invest in technology, whether it be organic or inorganic, and they will develop with their engineers acquired, they will be used to return cash, really return cash to shareholders. So we really believe that it's a win/win for our shareholders and a very special asset. I know there's a lot of worries about that, but I really do believe, and Bill and I have both had a lot of conversations with Michael Dell on their intentions, and their intention is to -- they get how special VMware is and what that can mean and that's going to generate value for you beyond just the initial whatever the deal goes down at. Because you get 0.11 shares for every EMC and then of course the common that's already out there. So I'm very comfortable this is going to be a great deal for all of you.

BILL GREEN: What surprised me, well the first thing that surprised me is it's easy to do these things wrong. It's really hard work to do them right. And it surprised me that for $100,000 and as many turkey club sandwiches I can eat for the last year I worked on this project, if you will, to get it right. And when I say get it right, I mean one is, find the real synergies. Find the real differentiation, find the nuggets. How hard it is to look under the hood of big companies like this that are incredibly diverse and complex. And you realize there are assets, knowledge and knowhow and talent that's been trapped in there and how you free that up and work through to find the case for not just cost synergies. I mean those are kind of shooting fish in the barrel. Revenue synergies, they're profound.

The second thing is, our board, the EMC board, on behalf of our shareholders, once we decided we were going to go this way, we solved for something called certainty to close. And certainty to close just rolls right off your tongue. But it's an incredibly complex set of legal and banking assistance to make sure that one you set on this path, you have arranged it so the deal is going to close unless an act of God happens essentially. Because that's the obligation we have to our shareholders. So just working through all the things on certainty to close.

And then it's complex, right? It's a big transaction. And it has its tracking stock in it. So people don't understand the tracking stock. We looked at every tracking stock thing that was ever set up over time through the heyday of it, through the falloff of it. We looked at all the legal considerations. Some of my board members call it putting the belt and suspenders around the agreement of the tracking stock. And then we looked at, you have this tracking stock, how do you get the governance right? How do you have common stock type governance in a tracking stock environment? And you make sure you build in all the legal and contractual things that you can influence to make sure that that stock that's going to be sort of unique to people that certainly went from the generation when we had those, understand the durability of the security and how it can operate. And so it was a profound amount of work to get to the signing in the fall, and it's turning out to be now a lot of work, and yet fun work, as we work through the process of not the regulatory approval and all that, but really the discovery of the golden nuggets that are in both companies that we can bring together in a synergistic way to add real value.

So the amount of work has been profoundly surprising to me. I am surprised at the reaction to the tracking stock. I do think there's people that just don't get it yet because it's not obvious, but the more people spend time on it, they're going to see and understand why this is a great transaction for the investors.

JOE TUCCI: And ultimately the tracking stock will highly depend on -- will depend on VMware's performance. Pat Gelsinger will be here tomorrow, he's the President and CEO for VMware, he'll talk to you about their strategy, their multi-cloud, multi-device strategy which I think is outstanding, and I encourage you to attend that session and you'll get a glimpse of what they're saying. But to echo, and kind of dig down one level deeper, we have a really, I think, very good, we've negotiated a very good merger agreement. I believe our performance relative to our peers is on par or better. And I talked to you about our last quarter was relatively flat, the previous 24 quarters we grew, 24 quarters in a row year on year. There's very few companies born when we were born that are doing that, very few, if any.

Secondly, our cash flow is great and right on track, so we have high confidence that this deal will close under the original terms on time.

DEBBIE GOLDMAN SACHS: So if we step away from the deal for a second, Joe, I was wondering, I mean we've had rocky times in the market since the calendar turned this year. I'm just wondering if you can give us a sense, how do you see IT budgets shaping up for 2016? When you're out there talking to customers, what are they saying to you today?

JOE TUCCI: First off all, I think when you think of IT budgets, they're changing. Because in yesteryear, IT budgets kind of came and were accumulated by the CIO themselves, in that department. And I think now what you're seeing is other departments, like marketing most notably, and others, have IT budgets in them. So I'm convinced if you look at shadow IT and the formal IT budgets for IT in other departments, I think the growth in IT is bigger than it comes across which is up a couple percent. That's number one.

Number two, I think customers are changing, and this goes back to the CIO. The CIO is changing a little bit of his buying patterns. And they're separating -- we see a separation, a careful separation of budgets into something that's more transformational in nature and something that's more transactional in nature. Transformational in nature is how do I get this company on a digital transformation agenda? How do I use this massive trove of information coming off of these Internet of Things devices, sensors, telemetry, smartphones, to really change the way I deal with my customers, with my supply chain, and become more intimate with my employees and partners? How do I do that? I mean those are transformational, becoming more of a software company itself, that's transformational. That's a budget. And how do I make sure that I'm going to be trusted and secure, cyber security? Those are viewed in the transformational bucket.

Then you get a transactional which basically covers most of the legacy systems. Which, by the way, companies still run tons of businesses on and they're very important. But there they're doing just enough just in time. So you see those trends hit and you look at just the, not the transformational budget, but you look at the transactional budget. They look like they're a little lumpy and that's because of this unbelievable, they've gone through incredible inspection, to make sure we're doing just what I need to buy now. Because I know the IT is going to change, and the CIO departments are putting new requirements on my desk every day, and I've got to create money for this new transformational side and then make sure I do just enough on the transactional side.

So that's a new phenomenon that we and all other customers are having to deal with. But I do believe when you look at that and the shadow IT budgets and the marketing budgets, there's a phenomenal future for IT. But it's changing and we've got to change with it.

DEBBIE GOLDMAN SACHS: I'm going to turn it over --

JOE TUCCI: Do you have anything to add to that?

BILL GREEN: No, I would just say as we provide governance to the company, there's plenty of legacy tech companies that are going off into the sunset. The question is, when you operate a company of size and scale like the EMC Federation is, how do you operate the company with one foot in today and one foot in tomorrow? And the foot in today is putting the plan in place and driving the business towards it and maintaining your market share or capturing market share. The foot in tomorrow is looking around the corner really on two dimensions.

One is, if you look at some of the new products that are coming on line from EMCII, first quarter, second quarter around flash, mainframe symmetrics, it's profound. The new products and technologies that are being driven into the market, these are must have kind of assets for anybody who has to keep the lights on and run the railroad at a customer's thing.

And then the other thing is the foot looking in tomorrow. If you look at the acquisitions and the investments in R&D that are the things that are going to be the billion dollar businesses of tomorrow, or $5 billion businesses of tomorrow, we as a board look at that and we see six or seven of these inside the EMC Federation. We've seen a few in VMware. We have Pivotal on its own. We have new things in the EMC, historic EMC family. And all those things are about important because you have to make today happen and tomorrow happen.

And so the budgets that are there today we feel good about our ability to be able to capture and be distinctive. And more importantly, the spending for tomorrow, that piece that's being freed up by cost cutting and customer companies today in order to invest in tomorrow, we feel good about as a company we have the assets. And at the end of the day, and I remember this from my history and my work experience, it's not clear how all this cloud digitization and so forth is going to shake out and there's profound uncertainty in the customers. So one of the things about putting these companies together, is I think it's going to be one of the most trusted providers of services and products in technology in history. And if you look at the biggest companies in the world, they want someone to go on the journey with them. I think that's why we translate today's activity in the market into the opportunity long term with the Dell/EMC combination.

SIMONA JANKOWSKI, ANALYST, GOLDMAN SACHS: To follow up on that, Joe, EMC has been talking the last few years about the third platform. Can you dig into what that really means and how you guys are putting it into practice?

JOE TUCCI: Assets that we have that are aimed clearly at the third platform would be more of our software defined assets. So if you're building a new application today and you're going to build the services and micro-services -- the buzzword of the industry is micro-services now, you've probably heard that 2,000 times at this conference. But if you're going to -- when you build those kind of services into the app or around the app itself, you can actually do different things in your infrastructure and make it much more cloud-esque. So obviously in that area, things we're doing with Pivotal with its first of all teaching customers how to fish again, which is basically teaching companies how to write software again, to be driving a cloud platform, a typical cloud platform that's cloud agnostic. And then three, helping customers analyze those huge troves of data that are being thrown at them. That's all third platform.

If you look at the software defined assets, the Viper, the -- let's use some names, ECS for Hadoop and Object Storage, vSAN from VMware, ScaleIO from EMC for block, OneFS for file, if you look at these software defined assets, they're more oriented towards tomorrow's (inaudible). And then of course you look at VMware's new strategies around NSX, around this growth strategy of multi-cloud, multi-device, and look at strategies around AirWatch, strategies around their management suite, they're very much placed for tomorrow. And also provider -- and the management suite also provides a bridge in everything products from today until tomorrow which is also going to be important. Because you know, tomorrow won't be all brand new applications and today won't be all old applications. You get this kind of mixture in the middle.

So I believe we have great assets And that's what I've been referring to as platform three, and that's what Bill was talking about. You've got to do the blocking and tackling which is probably a pot that is more of a zero sum game. When you get into zero sum games, everybody can't win. So you can get some of our peers are going to become much less relevant, they'll become irrelevant, and many will die. And then again, this is why getting the reach we're allowed with Dell at the SMBs, state and local governments, healthcare, departments of big companies, EMC's reach of the data center, of the biggest companies in the world. The leadership in servers, leadership in storage, leadership in virtualization, conversion infrastructure, etc. You put these together, this gives us massive opportunity to both help for today and tomorrow, And that's what's going to make a difference if the company can help with both, because that's what CIOs have, that's why they're working on the transformational and transitional budgets. They have to have a foot in both camps. And we uniquely can help them.

And again, from a VMware point of view, the majority of the software that we sell will come from VMware, so that will generate should be hopefully a good channel and outlook for them, too. So we really believe this will be a win/win/win. And again, the win/win/win is a win for you as shareholders, a win for our customers and a win for employees and partners. And those are the three buckets any CEO and any board worries about and obviously I put you first.

BILL GREEN: Yeah, I would just add to that, one of the transactions we did this year that the board was incredibly excited about was Virtustream. I mean this is an incredibly special company. This is very focused purpose cloud service environment that handles what the leader of that, Rodney Rogers, would describe as spinal fluid of companies. So it's not fringe cloud stuff, this is the heart and soul. And their stock in trade is to operate SAP in the cloud. And the momentum behind this business which sort of get lost in all the Dell and the transaction, is just profound, right? And it is built on the VMware platform and it is a peek at the future and how the former customers of Accenture are going to be operating their environments in a hybrid cloud kind of way, and Virtustream, which is part of this family of products and services, is going to be a big part of that.

SIMONA JANKOWSKI: Maybe just to follow up from that, so back at your Analyst Day last year in March, you guys talked about your expectation of consolidation in IT. And obviously we've now seen some of that happen. What are some of the benefits that you see from a scale perspective or otherwise, in having a very large hardware company versus some of the smaller hardware companies out there?

JOE TUCCI: Well hopefully we're not building a hardware company. We're building a hardware company, a software company both for today and tomorrow. So I think it's the breadth of what we have. Basically one of the things that I was most basically honored by and thrilled by, and I think Bill is in the same boat, is that if you look at what Michael Dell said he's going to do, he's following a bit of our federation strategy. And I think the benefit of having the mothership private gives you -- I think is actually a pretty good idea because it gives you an ability to incubate more things and then of course take them public eventually through the children so to speak. So I think that's really a profound advantage.

But I do think -- it's what I talked about before, it's just massive reach. I mean they are the king of the SMB market. Huge, huge footprint in state and local marketing in government state and even federal governments around the world. Huge footprint in hospitals. You look at EMC's footprints there, they're small, tiny Again, you go to the core datacenter, that's where EMC and VMware shine and of course Dell is not as prevalent there. So the ability to cross sell. And when you look at these things, you look the word synergies, and of course you focus on and you say, hey, they're pretty good operators, they'll get the cross synergies. But what makes me even more excited about it, and I really think they're real, is the revenue synergies are three times -- the cost synergies are real and sizable, but the revenue synergies are three times the cost synergies. And a number of those revenue synergies go to VMware, too.

So I think this is -- that's what makes me most excited about this deal. It wasn't long ago Dell was a big reseller of ours and just in one storage line they did almost $2 billion a year at the peak of our product. That just shows you the opportunity. And it also shows you that because we worked together for 7 years, people know each other. So it was a little bit of a homecoming when we finally got everybody together in the room and say, ah, I haven't seen you in five years, where have you been, you know. It's heartening. So that's kind of what I think is going to be the benefits.

BILL GREEN: Yeah, when we looked at that question from a board point of view, it was really important to us to understand not just where the synergies were, but sort of the broader opportunities in the market. So the first one was, how are buyers buying? And also to recognize that there's going to be someone who's going to be the de facto infrastructure provider of the future and it's not obvious who it is now. And so there's opportunities on that side.

The converged infrastructure momentum is just profound. So how do you move the business to where the buyer values are? And so one thing was consolidation to get scale and leverage. And if you just think of doubling the salesforce of people out there that can sell products that are attached to each other, you don't have to be a rocket scientist to figure out that you get huge lift from that.

But maybe one of the things that was really interesting to me, I had breakfast with a CEO of a big tech company, he's a good friend of mine, and it was one of those, this was in August, in the summer and this was one of those days when the market was jumping ugly. And we're trying to have a cup of coffee and every five minutes he's pulling out his phone, checking the share price. And so after about ten times, I'm like, how are you doing? And that evening we had dinner with Michael Dell and I said, Michael Dell, what were you doing today? And he said I sent a message to my employees and said isn't great to be a private company?

And I say that for this reason. Because incubation is a premium right now. And when you look at the ability to take the EMC, VMware family of assets, or Pivotal or any of these pieces, and incubate them out of harsh lights and then create and turn them loose on the market, it's a profound advantage of speed and keeps you from distraction. And so when we looked at what is it going to take to be a technology leader in the future, the ability to incubate was incredibly important to us in the assets that we had. And that's just another thing I think that comes with this consolidation thing.

SIMONA JANKOWSKI: And so you talked about it a little bit earlier, but Bill I think you mentioned like if the technology companies and the transformation, and we're not really sure how exactly the cloud is going to pay out. And I mean this with a lot of respect, Joe, because I've known you for a long time, but there is a boogieman in the room called public cloud that everybody is afraid of, at least from an enterprise legacy technology company perspective. Can you give us a sense for EMC and VMware the challenges that you think need to be overcome by each company and then the opportunities that cloud presents?

JOE TUCCI: I think any strategy that denies the existence and the success of the mega public cloud providers is foolhardy strategy. So I don't view it as the boogieman, I just view it as a fact of life. It rains somedays and it's sunny some days, just kind of facts of life. I can like it or dislike it. But basically, you've got to embrace it.

So for instance, on the Pivotal side, when you develop an application for this new world, it is from the get go able to run [on the cloud], it is able to run on Amazon, on Google, on Azure or on a VMware cloud, VMware-based cloud. That's what customers want, choice. Today we're the king of business continuance, backup disaster recovery, archives as part of our storage business. We understand that some of those VRs are going to go to a cloud. So therefore, you can fight it and first of all have our own offerings using Virtustream. But secondly, we'll say, okay, if you want to use Amazon or Azure, that's fine. And you could be a player at the software level.

VMware, when Pat presents it tomorrow, it's multi-cloud, multi-device strategy is all about being a cloud broker. How do you take applications and securely, seamlessly manage them and move them whether they're on your cloud in your datacenter, on a managed cloud, or in an Amazon or Azure. I mean that's where we're heading.

So basically what I see customers doing is there's very few customers are saying I'm putting everything on a public cloud. There's very few customers that are saying I'm doing only everything on a private cloud. And almost every customer I ask is doing something with a Salesforce or a WorkBay, or one of those kind. So they're managing or doing an application on a managed, hosted managed cloud. So that's the future. You're going to have managed clouds, and I put the SaaS providers in there. You're going to have private clouds, you're going to have public clouds. And how do you deal with all of them? And don't deny that these mega cloud providers are a real part, an important part of the future. And how do you play? And they're willing to play with us, too, and they're excited to play with us. Because in this new company, obviously they'll get some synergies, but we start out with like with 38,000 go to market people. 38,000. Unbelievable. That's sales, presales, management, etc. But that's a huge number.

We're a force. And that's part of the reason why this kind of merger, as Bill articulated, makes sense to us now. And if we do it right, and obviously the benefits will accrue to VMware and then the value will be more where you'll like it, and that's why we think this will be an attractive deal for you. And we've got to -- anytime we do something a little different, but again, we're doing a tracker and then also have a common. And usually in almost every tracker we looked at, there was no common. And those trade fairly -- in a much different range than the implied value of the trackers are trading today. So we think that we have confidence in this strategy, which is why we're saying to you it's going to benefit VMware, it's going to benefit other things we'll take public that you can participate in as we do those. A different set of decisions, but for you, they'll be open to you. And we think this is going to create a great future for this company that I helped build and love and Bill has come to love and is a great director and big in support of what we're doing. So that's kind of how I view the public cloud.

SIMONA JANKOWSKI: One of the other big trends I wanted to touch on is the move to converged infrastructure. I think, Joe, you said in the last earnings call that you think this year about 20% of storage will be sold as part of converged infrastructure. Can you just expand on that a little bit and how you see that featuring in your roadmap on a go forward basis?

JOE TUCCI: In a joint venture that Cisco -- EMC, VMware and Cisco started, VCE, we started the converged infrastructure. We thought it would be successful, it's way successful beyond our imagination. And then of course you've got hyper conversion and other plays, but basically it's conversion of infrastructure. And it's closer to what is happening in the cloud. Because customers don't want to spend the money buying piece parts, assembling those piece parts and keeping all those piece parts up to revs. So in other words, just in those pieces right there, there's a Cisco switch which has revs that it's putting out for its software and its products. In that is an EMC storage or multiple storage devices. Each of those has its cycles for upgrades and software cycles. And then you've got VMware virtualization and of course there's different products in there. So if you're a customer you've got to sit back and do all of that work yourself, assemble the hardware. And if you go converged, we're doing all that for you. It's closer to why you would buy a cloud. It has huge cost benefits to the customer.

So we will take this concept, and we start out with blocks, we'll take this concept through racks, through more of the third platform application, and we'll do appliances. So we are convinced that we will be the leader in converged infrastructure appliances, which are called hyper converged today, converged infrastructure racks and converged infrastructure blocks. We started with blocks, we're moving this way and stay tuned. I don't want to steal the thunder, but I think on February 16th you'll hear a lot more about that.

DEBBIE GOLDMAN SACHS: I think with that we have officially run out of time. So thank you, gentlemen, both for being here. Simona and I are pleased to have you, honored. Thanks again.

JOE TUCCI: Just a quick thing -- I want to just -- thank you, again. Bill noted that you usually don't take a director to a meeting with investors. I think that's yesterday's thinking. I think the directors represent you, I think you have every right and should know how the directors are doing for you. And this gives you a chance to meet a very experienced, very caring Lead Director. So I want to thank Bill for being with me and with you and on your behalf. And secondly, I want to let you know that we are confident this deal will happen. It will happen, we're confident it will happen in the original timeframe under the original conditions. And I want to thank you for your patience and thank you for your interest and I really appreciate the time you spent with us this morning. Thank you so much.

urn:contentItem:5DNB-FFK1-JB20-G3BY-00000-00EMC Corp at UBS Global Technology Conference - Final2014-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:31ZLexisNexis111914a5531020.720EMC Corp at UBS Global Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Jeremy Burton

EMC Corporation - President, Products & Marketing

Conference Call Participants

* Steve Milunovich

UBS Securities - Analyst

Presentation

STEVE MILUNOVICH, ANALYST, UBS SECURITIES: Why don't we get started? For the next session we've got EMC Corporation and we're very pleased to have with us again this year, Jeremy Burton, who is EVP of Product Operations and Marketing.

Jeremy, perhaps you could just start kind of bring us up to where EMC is today and give us a little summary and we'll go into Q&A.

JEREMY BURTON, PRESIDENT, PRODUCTS & MARKETING, EMC CORPORATION: Yes. Thanks, Steve. It's good to be back. I see the weather is the same as we had last year.

STEVE MILUNOVICH: That will make you feel at home.

JEREMY BURTON: Thanks. Last 12 months, probably make a couple of comments first, maybe start with the nature of customer conversations and then drill down specifically into some of the macro trends and the work that we've gotten done in the last year.

Customer conversations, very interesting, I think they've changed fairly dramatically. I've never been in so many conversations in the briefing center with business people. We typically tend to talk to the guys who are in infrastructure and IT. Increasingly we get access to executives and line of business executives. And probably most surprisingly in a number of those briefings, they don't actually bring the IT team with them and the topic of conversation increasingly is business transformation or digital transformation. If I'm a product company, how can I enhance my product with software, if I'm a services company, how can I deliver my services directly to a mobile device using software running on that mobile device?

So these conversations very quickly get to a point where paraphrase and they say, hey, I'd really like to become more of a software company. And that doesn't really matter which industry. I have seen this in sports retailers, I have seen it in automotive suppliers, pharmaceutical companies. So the conversation is very, very different and the lead in that conversation tends to be Pivotal. Those of you that are familiar might remember we set Pivotal up probably about 18 months ago to two years ago, really designed to build a new application and data platform to host these new kinds of applications.

The business transformation conversation invariably leads to a conversation around data center or IT transformation. That is more in the mainstream where VMware and EMC play. I would tell you in the last 12 months, you cannot have a meeting with the CIO, or a Head of Infrastructure without discussing a private and/or a hybrid cloud strategy and that's led us to do quite a bit of work in this area to deliver that hybrid cloud in a finite period of time for a finite amount of money. So both with business and with IT, I think the nature of the conversation has changed. Obviously, underpinning a lot of these top level drivers are things like cloud and mobile and social and big data, the four big tech trends, if you like.

And certainly as a family of companies, Pivotal, VMware, EMC, I think we've, at least to-date, been able to navigate those better than most. If you look at the last quarter with the top line growing 9% that certainly stacks up incredibly favorably versus large cap tech peers. And certainly if you take the last three years or so, we've consistently grown our top line up above, I think, probably 3% is the watershed that many of the large cap tech peers have been fallen below. I think we've only ever once managed to dip below that mark in the last 12 quarters.

One more comment then specifically around infrastructure, kind of very high level and how is the group doing, but specifically around infrastructure, which is the core part of the EMC information infrastructure business that I run, the first trend that in the last 12 months we've really been directly addressing is the move towards a flash technology in the data center.

I think when I sat here last year we didn't have our all flash array XtremeIO out in the marketplace. I sit here this year, we do. That product as we exited Q3 is on about a $500 million run rate. It was zero when I sat here last year. And I think if I was a betting man, I would say it reaches $1 billion, not just faster than any other EMC product in its history, including VMware, but I'd say it probably gets to $1 billion in half the time. So that obviously has been a big play for us.

We acquired a company early this year called DSSD. It's another play in the realm of flash. It is not a flash storage array. It is a server attached flash products and we think it's going to have a big role to play in memory databases and new applications that people will be building in future. So flash clearly a big deal, clearly something that we're addressing and we've got a couple of big things that we've rolled out in the last year.

The other extreme of things where people don't want incredible latency in performance, where they want economics, there's a trend towards software defined storage on commodity drives. You may be familiar, we introduced ViPR, a couple of years ago and then most recently we packaged ViPR with dense commodity hardware on something we call our Elastic Cloud Storage appliances. So if people are wanting object storage infrastructure like an Amazon S3 or they are wanting a block infrastructure like an Amazon EBS and they want to stand that up internally and provide self-service access to the application owners, that's what we provide through our software-defined appliances.

Up a level, converged infrastructure is a big trend. You might have noticed that we brought VCE into EMC Information Infrastructure that was a joint venture between EMC, VMware, Pivotal -- sorry, EMC, VMware, Cisco. We recently brought that back inside EMC, continues to do very, very well, last quarter growth above 50% now on a $2 billion run rate. And I think that decision gives us a lot more flexibility as to what we do in converged infrastructure in future. We also announced a little bit down market in hyper-converged infrastructure that we're going to be partnering with VMware on the EVO:RAIL project. So whether it's kind of departmental enterprise or whether it be data center, we feel that between the EVO:RAIL effort and VCE, we've got our bases covered.

And then finally on cloud, our latest announcement that we did, we set up about 15 months ago a joint lab between EMC, VMware, Pivotal to prove out customer solutions. Solution is probably the most overused term in tech. So let me be specific about what I mean. Proven out hardware, software plus a large amount of consulting intellectual property that we've used on prior engagements, we've packaged that together to deliver for the customer a hybrid cloud in 28 days. So obviously the packaged services offering is what allows us to start from the 50-yard line instead of -- have the customer start from the 50-yard line instead of the 10-yard line. STEVE MILUNOVICH: Let's talk a bit about the cloud. I think all the storage vendors are wrestling with how do they approach public and hybrid cloud. We had NetApp here today talking about their approach. You recently had an announcement. Could you take us through what EMC's approach is?

JEREMY BURTON: Yes, the thing we've heard time and time again and this has come back directly from the sales team is, look, you can't have a conversation with the CIO, or a Head of Infrastructure today without talking about a private cloud and then very quickly that turns to a hybrid cloud conversation.

So number one, the hybrid cloud in general, it's a very nebulous term, the customers in general don't really know what it is, what it entails, how much does it cost, how long does it take to put in, when am I done. And so what we've tried to do first and foremost is really demystify that.

So the hybrid cloud's announcement that we did was really the culmination of about 15 months' work that we did in conjunction with VMware and it was to say look, let's be very, very specific and write the recipe book around what a hybrid cloud environment entails. And then, not the hardware and software, but the key processes within IT that you would want to automate and you'd want to serve up in a self-service way what would they be, can we package that as well. And then can we deliver it in a very definite finite period of time.

So the enterprise hybrid cloud announcement really was saying, look, we can lay down a hybrid cloud foundation for you Mr. customer in 28 days. And the reason why it's 28 days and not six and nine months is because a lot of the services that we have delivered over the past year implement in this (inaudible) for many customers we have now packaged as a part of the overall solution.

That implementation comes ready to migrate workloads off to the VMware, Vcloud so they are a public cloud service. And in future it will support the migration of workloads to places like (inaudible) as well.

So first and foremost it was a job of really taking the mystery out of it through work in the lab that we've done with VMware. By the way there are a category of customers that we talk to that they are not going to go down the VMware path, they are going to go down the OpenStack path. And so you are going to see us next year also introduce a hybrid cloud stack that is going to have an OpenStack control plain on top of VMC storage and also a Microsoft control plain on top of VMC storage.

So our strategy here would be getting those conversations, take the mystery out of it for the customer and be able to deliver a full solution for a customer in a finite period of time for a finite amount of money.

If this turns into the next ERP implementation, then everything will go public cloud, right, because folks are not going to spend $100 million and wait two years in order to get a private or a hybrid cloud foundation down. And I believe at least, it's not really a technology issue at this point, it's delivering the solution to the customer and then helping the customer work through the organizational change that is required to adopt the new processes that are in a hybrid cloud.

STEVE MILUNOVICH: So you've got essentially a converged infrastructure product down the kind of private cloud side. I think it's a (multiple speakers)

STEVE MILUNOVICH: So you are basically talking about the NetApp and Equinix and -- Direct Connect, right.

JEREMY BURTON: It's called Direct Connect. We did it too, we just -- you don't see us making a big deal out of it because we don't think it's a big deal. Another option would be, instead of putting your storage at Amazon, leave your storage on premise and then maybe I can trickle data off to Amazon.

So TwinStrata and Maginatics, these are two companies that we've acquired that will allow us to move data from our primary storage arrays and from our backup products across the network and take advantage potentially of the public cloud economics. So again implementing your private cloud on-premise, that's one transformation and I think IT departments have to go through. Then there is maybe I could move some of my data off to Amazon through these gateways and that's what we bought to TwinStrata and Maginatics for and that could be primary storage data or it could be backup data.

I could say, hey, I want to move my storage entirely into that public cloud environment, so I can move it to the Equinixs data center, I can use the Amazon Direct Connect and I have then got peace of mind, so that's on my storage that I own and I'm leveraging the Elastic Compute. And then there is the ability to move the entire workload to the public cloud. So when we talked about enterprise hybrid cloud five minutes ago, I was talking more about that last used case where, hey Mr. customer we're going to make your environment into a private cloud, pooled resources, automation, self-service. We're going to give you the connectivity to the Vcloud Air and then you're going to stratify your workloads and you're going to make a call as to what you want you run on your own premise and what you are going to run in the cloud. And I think they're going to draw a line in the sand and say, you know what, these I'm going to have you manage because I'm going to manage those for cost and you're going to deliver me the service level. These, I want to manage on-premise because of the regulatory requirements. And I actually think that's how the majority of hybrid environments will work.

mean, as a tech industry, we love to talk about these great use cases of the end of the quarter and everything is going to burst magically to the public cloud and that's a niche. People are going to do workload analysis. They're going to stay, look these are Tier 1, they're running here, these are Tier 2 they're running here, these are Tier 3, they're running here. Some of those Tier 2 and Tier 3, I think will be in public cloud. I think for a long time to come the Tier 1 will likely be on premise and the line is going to be different depending on what kind of company you are talking to.

STEVE MILUNOVICH: Is this where VMware is pretty critical strategically to what you're doing where there is high alignment because I kind of view VMware to some degree as your cloud strategy? And if you were to separate, would you be able to do the same sorts of things through an alliance?

JEREMY BURTON: Yes. Alliance, I said solution was an overly used word in the tech industry. I'd say, alliance is probably another one. I guess, [apparently], you would say it's possible, because the degree of difficulty is much, much higher. I've worked in a lot of tech alliances over the last 20 years out here and look, it's just -- it's very, very difficult to get another company that you are unrelated to on the same page building technology and go into market together. There's got to be some kind of a forcing function.

And so, in direct response to your question, I'd say, yes, the VMware plays a very, very important role as we go talk to companies and how they want to move towards a hybrid cloud environment.

I was with a huge bank last week in Europe. This is the 40,000 virtual machine environment, right, I mean, that's like shockingly big. And look, it's an EMC VMware stack on the infrastructure with the Pivotal cloud Foundry on top for the next generation applications. And the thing, although it's not as relevant today, VMware EMC is very relevant today for that move.

In future I think the alliance with Pivotal becomes even more important because the next generation of applications are going to be built on some kind of new development platform and that's really what Pivotal is trying to provide. And if we want to be the infrastructure underneath that new development platform, then we will be well served to annex ourselves to Pivotal in the same way as in the last seven or eight years we've kind of annexed ourselves to VMware. That world is still getting going, so it's small revenue today, but I truly believe we're entering a period of time almost like the mid 1990s in application development where you're going to see massive amounts of custom software built. The debt platform is not going to be like a BEA application server and an Oracle database like it was back in the day. It's going to be something else.

And so, Pivotal are in the hunt for that something else and we want to be the infrastructure underneath that something else. And so, kind of going forward, I think they become arguably just as important to EMC is VMware are today.

STEVE MILUNOVICH: Competition. How do you currently view the landscape? Is there any change? You did say, you expect to grow three times the storage market rate obviously implying continued share gains. How difficult is that and earlier you mentioned to me that maybe you don't even focus as much on the traditional competitors going forward because the game is changing.

JEREMY BURTON: Yes, we certainly encounter our traditional competitors on a day-to-day basis. But, if you look at the growth dollars and where are those growth dollars going in storage, it tends to be more in these new areas like all flash arrays, like software defined. And so most of the kind of investment dollars, if you like, are starting to go into these new areas.

I mentioned earlier, I think when we first started off, the workloads in the data center are becoming incredibly latency sensitive. They are the perfect candidates for the all flash arrays. I mean, if you can guarantee a response time of less than a millisecond, a lot of performance issues go away in the data center.

So we certainly see that movement taking place. There's a whole new set of folks competing for the all flash array business. The only traditional competitor, we really see in that space is IBM with TMS. So IBM's legacy storage products are not doing that great. But I think, TMS at this point is probably still doing pretty well and I think, it's still a very, very viable competitor. But we believe by the time we exit this year our all flash business will be bigger than probably the next -- at least the next two combined and probably the next three vendors combined. And that was from a standing start back in this time last year.

So flash is a big deal, a lot of growth dollars. XtremeIO is one vector of innovation to intercept the trend. The other one that we have not talked about much is DSSD. And I think even to this day, if you go to dssd.com don't get set for an intense reading session. I mean there's really nothing out there.

So this is Bill Moore who is the -- [sits on] ZFS and he was one of the founders of 3PAR and Andy Bechtolsheim. They have built a dense, as the name suggests, dense SSD, dense flash storage offering but it's actually not really a storage array. It doesn't talk like (inaudible) and all the weird and wonderful protocols that we've used over the years. It talks the language of the application, it talks HDFS and it talks key value. And the reason it does that is this thing is designed as a real latency monster. I do believe in the new world that we're heading into where everybody has got access to their applications through mobile devices, you're going to get lots of streams of information. And instead of us doing transaction processing, again a world I came from, Oracle database is transaction processing, instead of processing transactions, we are going to process streams. And those streams are going to need to be processed in memory, because often, you're going to be dealing with the consumer where we all sit there with iPhones, man, when is this thing going to respond. So I think in-memory computing is going to be a huge deal.

And if you look at what's going to be required from a storage standpoint for in-memory systems, you're going to need an order of magnitude better latency and an order of magnitude more bandwidth. And so the DSSD, we have moved the storage from the other side of the network on to the service side. But it is still a shared storage and it plugs into compute through PCIe3 and I think some of the latency and the performance characteristics of this we think are going to be groundbreaking and we're pretty bullish on it coming out next year.

And I think, again tapping into new vectors of growth in the storage industry. If in-memory is big, if a lot of these new applications use in-memory, that's something that I think we're well placed to tap into that nobody else is. And so that's what we should be able to charge a premium for. So XtremeIO, DSSD the software defined components on commodity so the [sea word] was probably not a very nice word and it didn't exist in EMC's vocabulary two or three years ago. Let's be that definitive. But look, you get a lot of companies that come into our briefing centre enamored with the Google, Amazon way of working and they are like, hey, I want a software defined storage strategy that runs on commodity drives. And so the ViPR project that we started three or four years ago, there is a whole bunch of the team that did ASIO for Microsoft came to EMC to build out ViPR. That really is still early days. It's in its version two incarnation, but we'll start to see a lot of pickup in that because we've packaged ViPR with dense commodity storage.

And so if you are an IT department and you say, hey look, I want to stop the Shadow IT going out to Amazon S3, I want a self-service environment that I can stand up and get running in minutes, that's what the elastic cloud storage appliances does. You plug it in and off you go. You've got self-service access via developers to get Amazon S3 like environment.

So again, that though I think is, in a lot of ways like a new growth vector and what we're really doing here is, is we see the high-end under pressure. We've got to tap into these new growth vectors so that overall we can continue to not just grow our business but grow it the 3x the storage market growth that has always been our goal for the last few years.

urn:contentItem:5MF0-PVF1-JD1P-T3G0-00000-00Emerging Europe: Lithuania goes all in on fintech2016-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:42:31ZLexisNexisFEATURE,CENTRAL AND EASTERN EUROPE,BANKING,EUROMONEY,CAPITAL MARKETS,EMERGING MARKETSEmerging Europe: Lithuania goes all in on fintechLucy Fitzgeorge-Parker

Of all the cities lining up to poach London's business post-Brexit, Vilnius might seem the most unlikely. Yet the Lithuanian capital has much to offer financial firms, from liveability and local talent to cutting-edge fintech regulation. Euromoney visits a small city with big ambitions.

--Leafy, low-rise and elegant, Vilnius is relatively free from traffic-
Ever since the UK's Brexit vote in June, cities across the continent have been lining up to lure financial firms away from London. All the usual suspects "" Paris, Frankfurt, Dublin, Amsterdam "" have rushed to make the case for becoming Europe's new banking centre.One of the very first pitches, however, came from a more unlikely source. A week after the referendum, hundreds of UK-based banks, hedge funds and fintech firms received a letter from a Lithuanian poker player-turned MEP."You must be thinking about where to relocate your EU operations," wrote Antanas Guoga "" or Tony G, as he is known at the tables. "I would like to invite you to explore Vilnius." And, for anyone who was unsure where that was, he helpfully added: "The capital of Lithuania."At first glance, a former Soviet city of half a million people in the northeastern corner of Europe seems an unlikely spot for a global financial hub. Yet, as Guoga pointed out, Vilnius has already attracted a clutch of big tech and banking names. Barclays, Danske Bank and Nasdaq have large operations centres there, while Uber chose the city for its first IT development centre outside Silicon Valley.So what does Vilnius have to offer? "Great prices and great quality of life, together with a multilingual talent hub of hard-working, tech-minded and creative high-achievers," according to Guoga.He added: "Vilnius is open, flexible and business-friendly. We will get you everything you need."As a publicity stunt, the letter was highly effective. Journalists desperate for Brexit news were understandably amused by the idea of Vilnius setting itself up as a competitor to London or Frankfurt. But could an obscure Baltic capital live up to the hype? Two months later, Euromoney travelled to Lithuania to find out.--MEP Antanas Guoga
One thing that is immediately apparent from a quick tour of the city is that Guoga's talk about its liveability is justified. Leafy, low-rise and elegant, Vilnius is relatively free from traffic, but packed with hipster coffee shops, bars and high-quality restaurants.English is spoken everywhere and, unlike the other Baltic centres, Riga and Tallinn, there is almost no trace of Lithuania's Soviet past. There is, however, plentiful evidence of Vilnius's recent success in attracting western business. Over the past decade, shiny new glass buildings emblazoned with the logos of global blue chips have sprung up all along the north bank of the narrow Neris River.Easily the most eye-catching of these is Barclays' Lithuanian headquarters, an elliptical 14-storey structure that towers over the sprawling red roofs of its neighbour, the University of Educational Sciences.The UK bank was the first big player to set up in Vilnius, establishing a shared service centre in 2009. At the time, Lithuania was in the middle of a particularly sharp post-financial crisis recession, which saw the economy shrink by nearly 15% in one year. The country was also still off the radar for global firms.Mariano Andrade Gonzalez, chief operating officer of Barclays Lithuania, says this was one of the main factors that attracted the bank to the country."We looked at Poland and Ukraine, but we chose Lithuania because of the high quality of the talent pool and the lack of competition," he says. "It was relatively easy to ramp up."Barclays has certainly done that. From humble beginnings as a technical support centre for the bank's staff, Vilnius has over the past six years been transformed into one of its key global operations and development hubs.Top choiceToday, the riverside tower and a second location to the northeast of the city centre house dozens of teams covering functions from change management and mobile development to cybersecurity. Since 2014, Vilnius has been designated as one of Barclays' two global human resources hubs, along with Chennai, and one of four global attack monitoring teams is based here."We can't show you it," says Gediminas Mikaliunas, head of workspace and user experience. "It's in a secret room on a secret floor." Sadly, he appears to be joking.Euromoney does, however, get to see some of the less sensitive parts of Barclays' offices, which in true tech style are lavishly equipped with whiteboards, beanbags and adjustable-height desks. The staff is young "" the average age is 29 "" and, apparently, hyper-fit. Gonzalez notes proudly that 15% of his employees ran the Vilnius marathon this year. We've never seen in any countries such a push for innovation," he says. "Regulators are usually more like policeman -Nikolay Storonsky,Revolut Some come from outside Lithuania, but many have been trained up by Barclays, which has worked with local universities to ensure a ready supply of skilled talent for the bank's more rarefied divisions.Vilnius University now offers a masters degree in cybersecurity, thanks in part to Barclays' efforts, and has also helped the bank set up training programmes for mainframe and iOS operating systems. The iOS app for Barclays' Pingit mobile payment system was developed in Vilnius.Mikaliunas says this flexibility is one of the key advantages of working in a small market such as Lithuania: "You have great collaboration from the government and from the education system, so you can shape the future of the services you want to deliver."Barclays is also looking to tap into a growing pool of local fintech talent in Lithuania and its former Soviet neighbours in eastern Europe, including Belarus and Ukraine. In July, the bank chose Vilnius as the location for its seventh Rise centre.Formerly known as Barclays Escalator, Rise is a global network of fintech communities designed to allow the bank to foster development in areas such as artificial intelligence, virtual reality, blockchain technology and big data away from the constraints imposed by strict compliance requirements. Other venues are located in New York, London, Manchester, Tel Aviv, Cape Town and Mumbai."It's a way for us to engage in a completely different model of innovation," says Gonzalez. "We draw up a list of problems that Barclays wants to resolve in each location, then we approach venture capital firms and ask what they have in their portfolios."In Vilnius a top priority is artificial intelligence, which Barclays sees as the future of technical support for its global workforce."We are investing heavily in moving from old-style telephony to modern digital channels, from online portals to chatbots and robotic process automation," says Mikaliunas.--Mariano Andrade Gonzalez, chief operating officer of Barclays Lithuania-
Housed in an airy building just across the river from Barclays' Lithuanian HQ, Rise Vilnius has 50 working spaces, a café (you can order and pay for your latte in advance on your mobile, naturally) and a conference hall.At the time of Euromoney's visit, the latter is hosting Lithuania's first ever fintech conference. Organized by the central bank and finance ministry, the event includes panels on topics such as payment innovations and blockchain, with speakers from as far afield as Israel and Hong Kong.A highlight of the morning session is the signing of a memorandum of understanding between the central bank and Revolut, a start-up offering cut-price cross-currency transfers and payments. Set up by two former Credit Suisse bankers, the firm is based in London but plans to open a second office in Vilnius.Nikolay Storonsky, CEO and co-founder, says the choice of location was driven partly by the need for an EU base "" he is not convinced that the UK will retain passporting rights after Brexit "" but mainly by Lithuania's progressive approach to fintech regulation."We've never seen in any countries such a push for innovation," he says. "Regulators are usually more like policeman."Payments and e-money firms can get licensed in less than three months in Lithuania, much faster than even in other tech-friendly jurisdictions. From January, they will also be able to apply for a restricted banking licence, similar to that introduced in the UK in 2013, which will drastically reduce capital requirements (to as low as â,¬1 million ($1.07 million)) for firms involved in basic transaction banking.Still more important for Revolut, says Storonsky, is the fact that non-banks in Lithuania can already get direct access to the Single euro payments area (Sepa) infrastructure."We're ahead of even the UK on this one," says Marius Jurgilas, a board member at the Bank of Lithuania. "Mark Carney has said they're looking to do this in two years' time."Lithuania has also passed laws this year regulating peer-to-peer lending and crowdfunding; legislation on remote identification is being prepared. Other fintech-friendly initiatives include the creation of a regulatory sandbox for start-ups, whereby 45 other Lithuanian state institutions "" including the tax inspectorate "" have agreed to waive sanctions in a firm's first year of supervision.BlockchainPolicymakers are particularly keen to take a lead on blockchain. Local venture capital firm Nextury Ventures hosted a blockchain and bitcoin conference in Vilnius in April, in conjunction with the mayor's office, and Jurgilas says the central bank is in talks with several bitcoin exchanges about the possibility of issuing them with e-money licences."They are looking for a regulator who would be willing to give them a stamp of approval," he says. "We understand that we would be sticking our head very high, but we are ready to do that."He is eager to stress that the central bank's enthusiasm for innovation is as much about cutting costs for consumers as it is about making life easier for start-ups. Lithuania's banking sector is highly concentrated; three lenders, SEB, Swedbank and DNB account for more than 90% of the market."The general perception is that banks are overcharging their clients, so there is huge pressure on politicians and regulators to improve competitiveness," says Jurgilas. "That's why we are keen to embrace fintech."--Marius Jurgilas, a board member at the Bank of Lithuania-
At the same time the push to liberalize financial regulation is in line with broader efforts to position Lithuania as a business and tech-friendly jurisdiction. A more flexible national labour code was introduced in September, while visa restrictions for skilled workers and start-ups have recently been relaxed as part of a drive to attract tech talent from eastern Europe to Lithuania.Vilnius's mayor, Remigijus Simasius, says the initiative is already showing results: "Entrepreneurs and IT specialists from Belarus, Ukraine and even Russia are starting to move here." He notes that more than two dozen Russian gaming start-ups have set up shop in Vilnius.Daumantas Dvilinskas, head of local payments firm TransferGo, says bringing in talent from outside Lithuania is becoming a priority as more and more companies move to Vilnius."The market is getting saturated," he says. "We only have a few thousand people graduating with tech degrees in Lithuania every year, and every firm that comes here wants to hire thousands."Recent arrivals such as AIG and Nasdaq, which opened an "~innovation hub' in Vilnius last year, are ramping up rapidly, while established players such as Barclays, Western Union and Danske Bank also continue to expand. Western Union now employs more than 2,000 staff at its European regional operations centre in the northern Baltupiai district."Every company I know that has invested in Lithuania, especially in shared service centres, has exceeded their most optimistic prognosis in terms of expansion," says Simasius.NicheDespite these successes it would be hard to say that Vilnius currently qualifies as even a regional financial centre. So, is it really credible to expect UK banks and fintechs fleeing Brexit to relocate en masse to a remote corner of the Baltics?Clearly not, says Bank of Lithuania's Jurgilas."We are not dreaming of having the headquarters of Goldman Sachs in Vilnius just because we have some nice parks," he says. "We are fishing at the bottom. We have something to offer in a very specific niche."Far from looking to compete directly with London, he sees the UK capital as a key partner for Vilnius in its fintech development drive."Seed capital isn't located in Lithuania," he says. "If you want investors, you need to jump on a stage in London."This is also the message from Jeremy Browne, a former Liberal Democrat minister in the UK's coalition government, who now holds the thankless post of special representative to the EU for the City of London.In opening remarks to a packed auditorium at the Vilnius fintech conference, he says London's goal is to work with, rather than against, cities such as Vilnius before and after Brexit.TransferGo: the need for speed-The tendency of foreigners to confuse Lithuania and Latvia is a standing joke among locals. For a pair of Lithuanian students, it was also the inspiration for one of the country's most successful start-ups.In 2011, Daumantas Dvilinskas and Justinas Lasevicius were studying in the UK and running a small import-export business. They were using banks for international money transfers, which was expensive and very slow.Then one day, their UK bank mixed up the Lithuanian and Latvian currencies "" litas and lats "" and sent their cash to the wrong country. To add insult to injury, it refused to compensate them for the mistake. In despair, Lasevicius suggested using his personal accounts in the UK and Lithuania for local transactions and then netting off payments at the end of the day."And it worked" says Dvilinskas. "The supply chain was happy because we were paying out money in real time and the cost plummeted becausethere were fewer international payments."And then the revelation came"¦"The result of this eureka moment was TransferGo, a payments firm that uses partner banks in countries across Europe and beyond to provide low-cost, real-time money transfers."We call it a local-in, local-out model," says Dvilinskas.Fees are based on speed "" starting from 99p for next-day delivery "" and, for cross-currency transfers, transaction size. For payments over £1,000, the currency conversion fee is 0.4%.Dvilinskas says transfer time is particularly important for the blue-collar migrant workers from central and eastern Europe that make up the firm's core customer base: "People are willing to pay for speed."TransferGo's expansion has been rapid. Four years after launch, the firm is processing 45,000 transactions a month with a value of around £15 million ($18.7 million). It is the market leader for remittances from the UK to the Baltics and in the top five for Poland."The beauty of our model is that revenues are very predictable," says Dvilinskas. "Pay-day remitters are like clockwork."Surprisingly, he is not dismayed by the Brexit vote."There are seven million migrant workers in the UK," he says. "They won't disappear overnight. Maybe in a few years they will reshuffle, but they will be working somewhere."In the short term, he adds, the referendum was good for business: "June and July were record months for us. People were nervous about the pound dropping, so they were sending all their money back home."Any adverse effects further down the line should also be diluted by TransferGo's expansion into new global markets. The firm has recently added India, Ukraine and the Philippines to its growing list of transfer destinations, and is targeting Russia and China next."We are trying to link up Europe with the major currencies of the world," says Dvilinskas.

"We're not here to see what we can take from Lithuania," he says. "We want to help you realize your ambitions by providing access to the scale and expertise that London can offer."

Even the ebullient Guoga, who made headlines in July when he applied to run as a pro-European candidate to replace Nigel Farage as leader of Britain's nationalist UK Independence Party, admits that global banks will not be moving their front office staff to Lithuania. "For now," he adds.

At the same time, he says, the Brexit vote offered a great opportunity to "reach out and tell people that Vilnius exists, that Barclays is here and is happy, and that we have a lot of smaller companies working in the fintech space".

This highlights the fact that the biggest challenge for globally minded policymakers in Lithuania is still the country's international reputation "" or, rather, its lack of one. Outside emerging Europe, many people have not heard of Lithuania, and, Guoga notes, those that have often tend to confuse it with Latvia.

"When we started thinking about developing a financial hub in Vilnius, we immediately realized that what we've been doing wrong is that no one knows about this opportunity," says Jurgilas. "They don't know that we have such a wealth of tech talent here, that all the innovative payment development IT guys are based here."

As more and more firms move to Vilnius, however, the message is gradually reaching a wider audience. "The fact that Nasdaq has set up here has really helped with Americans," says Guoga. "Previously they thought Lithuania was a just a backward place somewhere far away that they probably wanted to avoid."

(There is clearly still work to be done on brand recognition in the US "" an American tech journalist at the Vilnius conference tells his hosts how delighted he is to be in the Balkans.)

The famous Brexit letter has also produced results, according to Guoga.

"We've had hundreds, thousands of replies," he says. "We even had a response from HSBC." He adds that he hopes to bring a "fairly big" hedge fund to Vilnius "fairly soon".

He is confident that Lithuania's capital "" of which he is chief investment officer "" has a very bright future. For fintechs in particular, he insists, Vilnius is "number one".

He says: "If you are a start-up with 20 staff, and you want to be able to talk to the central bank and compete all over the world from a eurozone country, we are the best place in the world."

Never one to underplay his hand, Guoga adds: "If we start now and work really hard, maybe in 20 to 25 years we can be half the size of London as a financial city."

It is a bold call, but then again, post-Brexit there is all to play for in Europe. There seems no reason why Vilnius should not be able to take a share of the spoils.
